comment_on_borrowed:
Cf. Maanyan ini ‘urine’ and amini ‘to urinate’.
Dahl’s (1988:103) endeavour to trace amani to Swahili and Comorian is contrived and leaves too many questions (cf. Proto Bantu *-nyi-, Swahili ku-nya ‘to emit, drop; to urinate’, Shinzuani hu-nya kójo, Shingazija u-nyawa ‘to urinate’)

The South East Barito ancestral form may have been borrowed. As Malagasy as a rule lost Proto Malayo Polynesian final *s, the evidence hinges on Maanyan m-anros ‘to bathe’ (Dahl 1951:306); if this word were inherited from Proto Malayo Polynesian *diRus ‘to bathe’, it should have lost final /s/

comment_on_word_form: cf. mitoetra (7.11) ‘to dwell’, toerana (12.11) ‘place’

comment_on_borrowed:
Malagasy mòra and its Malay and Javanese cognates ultimately derive from an earlier (Proto Malayo Polynesian?) *qudaq ‘young’.
The meaning of mòra as well as the fact that it has a fossilised initial m indicate that it must be an adoption from Javanese (either directly or via Malay); compare furthermore Maanyan murah ‘easy’ which must be borrowed from Javanese (and probably via Malay) on account of its fossilised m- and its irregular final h.

other_comments: Gonda speculates that the origin of satria and Malay sǝdia may be a conflation of the Sanskrit words sādhya- ‘accomplished, prepared, attainable’ and sajja- ‘ready’.

other_comments: also spelled maotera

comment_on_word_form: nimerào < French ‘numèro’; aotomobìla < French ‘automobile’

comment_on_borrowed: Cf. 24.04. The root ìsy  is probably borrowed on account of its /s/; the use of (b-)isi as an existential marker is also seen in Iban and some other Malayic varieties in Borneo; South East Barito languages in Borneo do not seem to have a cognate.

comment_on_borrowed: the constituent parts of this term are borrowed: ra- ‘HON’ is adopted from Javanese; -fòzana < Malay moyaŋ ‘ancestors’ < *əmpu ‘lord’ + *hiaŋ ‘deity’

gloss: fi- -ana ‘NOUN’ + an-dòha ‘at the head’ (< aN- ‘LOC’ + lòha ‘head’)
voa- (resultative prefix) + loha ‘head’ + ny (possessively used definite article, “[of] it”)

other_comments: Borrowed from vernacular Arabic. Cf. Shinzuani mkiri, Shingazija msihiri, Swahili moskiti (meskiti, msikiti); cf. also msikiri in the coastal languages Vumba and Chifunde (southern coast, Kenya, cf. Nurse and Hinnebush 1993:665). The additional final syllable -ny must be due to the tendency to restore regular stress patterns (Dez 1964).

borrowed_base: tsy is not South East Barito; it is probably borrowed from Malay, cf. ti/- in Malay ti-ada ‘there is not’

comment_on_word_form: historically related to fàty ‘corpse’, cf. 4.77

comment_on_borrowed: Initial syllable suggests adoption from a Bantu language

Cf. 24.04. The root ìsy  is probably borrowed on account of its /s/; the use of (b-)isi as an existential marker is also seen in Iban and some other Malayic varieties in Borneo; South East Barito languages in Borneo do not seem to have a cognate.

gloss: aN- 'LOC' + àty ‘liver; the inside, centre of the senses’
